messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Tight Bounds for Black Hole Search in Dynamic Rings

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we start the investigation of distributed computing by mobile agents in dangerous dynamic networks. The danger is posed by the presence in the network of a black hole (Bh), a harmful site that destroys all incoming agents without leaving any trace. The problem of determining the location of the black hole in a network, known as black hole search (Bhs), has been extensively studied in the literature, but always and only assuming that the network is static. At the same time, the existing results on mobile agents computing in dynamic networks never consider the presence of harmful sites. In this paper we start filling this research gap by studying black hole search in temporal rings, specifically focusing on 1-interval connectivity adversarial dynamics. Clearly the task is dangerous for the agents, as any agent entering the Bh will be destroyed; the problem is solved if within finite time at least one agent survives and knows the location of Bh. The main complexity parameter of Bhs is the number of agents (called size) needed to solve the problem; another important parameter is the number of moves (called cost) performed by the agents; in synchronous systems, such as temporal rings, an additional complexity measure is the amount of time until termination occurs. Feasibility and complexity depend on many parameters; in particular: whether the agents start from the same safe node or from possibly distinct safe locations, the size nùëõn of the ring, whether or not nùëõn is known, and the type of inter-agent communication (whiteboards, tokens, face-to-face, visual). In this paper, we provide a complete feasibility characterization for all instances of those parameters; all our algorithms are size optimal. Furthermore, we establish lower bounds on the cost (i.e., the number of moves) and time of size-optimal solutions for all instances of those parameters and show that our algorithms achieve those bound. keywords: Mobile agents, black hole search, dynamic ring.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "DMVP: Foremost waypoint coverage of time‚Äìvarying graphs",
        "Continuous aggregation in dynamic ad-hoc networks",
        "Deterministic dispersion of mobile robots in dynamic rings",
        "Exploring an unknown dangerous graph with a constant number of tokens",
        "Self‚Äìstabilizing robots in highly dynamic environments",
        "Computability of perpetual exploration in highly dynamic rings",
        "Gracefully degrading gathering in dynamic rings",
        "Measuring temporal lags in delay-tolerant networks",
        "Time-varying graphs and dynamic networks",
        "Black hole search with finite automata scattered in a synchronous torus",
        "Tight bounds for black hole search with scattered agents in a synchronous ring",
        "Complexity of searching for a black hole",
        "Searching for a black hole in synchronous tree networks",
        "Compacting and grouping mobile agents on dynamic rings",
        "Exploring and making safe dangerous networks using mobile entities",
        "Mobile Agents on Dynamic Graphs, Chapter 20 of [31]",
        "Brief announcement: Investigating the cost of anonymity on dynamic networks",
        "Distributed exploration of dynamic rings",
        "Gathering in dynamic rings",
        "Exploring an unknown dangerous graph using tokens",
        "Searching for a black hole in arbitrary networks: optimal mobile agents protocols",
        "Mobile search for a black hole in an anonymous ring",
        "Locating a black hole in an un‚Äìoriented ring using tokens: The case of scattered agents",
        "Scattered black hole search in an oriented ring using tokens",
        "On temporal graph exploration",
        "A game of cops and robbers on graphs with periodic edge-connectivity",
        "Ping pong in dangerous graphs: optimal black hole search with pebbles",
        "Map construction and exploration by mobile agents scattered in a dangerous network",
        "Searching for black holes in subways",
        "On the exploration of time-varying networks",
        "Distributed Computing by Mobile Entities",
        "Tight bounds on distributed exploration of temporal graphs",
        "Lower bounds on information dissemination in dynamic networks",
        "Exploration of constantly connected dynamic graphs based on cactuses",
        "Exploration of the T‚Äìinterval‚Äìconnected dynamic graphs: the case of the ring",
        "Using periodic contacts for efficient routing in delay tolerant networks",
        "Hardness and approximation results for black hole search in arbitrary networks",
        "Approximation bounds for black hole search problems",
        "Gradient clock synchronization in dynamic networks",
        "Distributed computation in dynamic networks",
        "Live exploration with mobile robots in a dynamic ring, revisited, 2020",
        "Identifying hostile nodes in networks using mobile agents",
        "Black hole search and exploration in unoriented tori with synchronous scattered finite automata",
        "Dangerous Graphs, Chapter 18 of [31]",
        "Traveling salesman problems in temporal graphs",
        "Information dissemination in highly dynamic graphs",
        "Repairing faulty nodes and locating a dynamically spawned black hole search using tokens"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Tight Bounds for Black Hole Search in Dynamic Rings, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
